text: the British Virgin Islands look like
they've been hit by the blast wave of a
bomb on the biggest island of Tortola
houses have been ripped apart and
contents scattered for miles and over
20-foot we've searched crushed boats
reaching them among the rubble they
started off with wind or in Glasgow was
at home as Burma hit this section of my
my mom's room the roof came off then my
bedroom came off we wanted a living room
glass I the boss we had all this bought
it up
he lost everything everything
people talk about the winds that came
through here as if they were alive as if
it comes from another world and now five
days after the hurricane struck that in
desperate need of food of shelter and
clean water others are just simply
desperate to leave the shock of seeing
this terrifying force of nature is
overwhelming some are trying to fly home
to relatives in the UK the Masen family
made it to the shelter after neighbors
with machetes hacked through debris to
help them hike from their damaged home
literally this morning was the first
time we'd really had any news at all of
what was happening some residents have
criticized the UK government's response
to this crisis as pathetic and slow
there are also reports of looting across
the island as many are desperate for
basic supplies there are large queues
for food and for petrol
help has now arrived the British
military have brought heed and are
already reestablishing order they're
working on a plan to try to restore
power and water one woman told me she
wept with relief as she saw the plane
land hurricane Hermes trail of
destruction is vast and yet the
Caribbean spirit prevails as our team
walked the streets so many people told
us the same message
they are simply grateful to be alive
Laura Becker BBC News Tortola

you
